titleStmt.title: An enterlude of welth, and health ... newly ... imprinted. The names of the players. Welth. Helth, Lybertie. ...

note.p: Printer's and publisher's names and publication date conjectured by STC.
Imperfect; title page stained, obliterating some print.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Header created with script marc2tei.pl on 2001-12-12.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. Digital page images are linked to the text file.

div.p: An ente●●●●● of Welth, and Helth, very m●●y and 〈◊〉 Pastyme, newly 〈◊〉〈◊〉〈◊〉 Imprinted.
Foure may easely play this Playe.

div.stage: ¶Here entreth Welth, and Helth synging together a balet of two partes, and after speaketh Welth.
div.l: WHy is there no curtesy● now I am come
I t●owe that all the people be d●me
Or els so god helpe me and halyd●●●
No wordes I harde, no● yet no ●●lking
No instrument went nor ballattes synging
What ayles you all thus ●● syt dreaming
Of my coming ye may be ●l●d
For all your desyre shall be had
By God I thinke ye haue forgotten me.
I am welth of this realme looke vpon me
For I am to euery man louing and fre●ndly

sp.speaker: Helth.
sp.l: Brother welth haue ye not yet doone?
ye prayse your selfe aboue the moone
Euery man may perceyue therby soone
That you lacke discresyo●

sp.speaker: We●th.
sp.l: Wherfore, by god I cannot say to much
I am so welthy of substaunce and rych
In all the worlde where is one such
As I am of comparison.

sp.speaker: Helth.
sp.l: Welth is good I cannot den●y
Yet prayse your selfe so muche ye may
For welth oftentimes doth decay
And welth is nothing s●re.

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Welth hath ben euer in thi● countrey
And here I p●rpose styll for to be
For this is the lande most mete for me
And here I wyll endure.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Therin ye speak●full louingle
For in this realme welth should be
yeth no displeasure I pray you hartely
But in the way of communicacion.
And for pastyme I would ●peake some wayes
Of no comparison, nor to you no dysp●yre,
I doo not intende that maner alwayes,
But for a recreation,

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Brother wh●t soeuer ye say to me.
I wyll heare yo● p●ci●●tly
I am content and I 〈◊〉 you hartely
Begyn and say your pleasur●

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: I thanke you h●●●●ly th●● wyll I
Some what vnto my purpose apply
Though welth be praised maru●lu●ly
yet to myne vnderstauding.
Welth is mutable, and th●t in shame
And welth is hauty and proude of name
Welth t● cruell, and in great blame
For welth is ●●er wauerynge.

sp.speaker: w●alth.
sp.l: To whom haue I doone any harme can ye say,
ye stander me no●e, yet I trust I may
Aunswere for my selte in euery maner way
ye wyl not deny that?

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: God forbyd but ye should d● so
And ye may doo it whe●her I wyl or no
Inlykewise, I must answer you als●
When ye say not true.
Though I be but to you a poore man
yet helth I height, the same I am
That is desyred vniuersally than
Some calles me as good as you

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: As I, mary ther in deede ye do compare.
Such wordes myght brynge you soone in care
Lewde parson, thou art not ware
Of what substaunce I am

sp.speaker: Health.
sp.l: Yes I can tell what you are, be not dyspleased
welth is of great substaunce, that cannot be denyed
yet shew your comodities, and ye shalbe answered
I promyse you wellh is fugitiue.

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: What sayst thou`am I a tagetyue
I was neuer so taken vp in my lyfe
Nor called vnsure, well I wyll make no stryfe
yet where as thou dost lay,
Thai I should shew my commodityes alwayes
The best for my selfe wherof I aske prayse
yf I shoulde staud her all my lyfe dayes
yet I coulde not say.
Nor halfe the benefites that commeth of me
yt cannot be tolde nor resyted shortly
Welth is the 〈◊〉 of althing earthly
That you cannot denye.
Ferste god saue, our soueraine Ladye the Queene
With all the counsel and all that wish them b●ne
Am not I welth with them euer at eue
Who should be there but I?
Men of the lawe, and ioly rych marchauntes
There be welthy both of goodes and lands,
Without comparyson is in their handes
I walth hatg all freasure.

sp.speaker: Health.
sp.l: O good syr, of whom commeth all this
Of god only, to yo● no thanke I wys
And yet mans welth ●tands not all in ryches
I dare saye that boldly,
W●an a man hath a cempetent liuing
with the grace of god that passeth all thyng
Loue of his neyghbour, aud good reporting
Then is he welthy,
Welth of goodes is but a fame
Ye is wel●hy that hath a good name
Euery wyse man wyll coueyte the same
For other welth I not reche
yf a man haue neuer so much good name
Euery wise man wyll couey●e the same
if his disposicions be nought aud wood
Then he is but a wretch,

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Nay thou art a wretch, and a foole vuwyse
welth of ryches thus to despyse
Doest thou not se all the worlde aryse
By goodes and substaunce
He that hath plenty of syluer and golde
May haue all thyng whatsoeuer he woulde
whan can welth lacke, seing all thing is solde
A●d welth is of assuraunce.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: I deuye that, your saying is nought
Grace● heauen, nor cunning, cannot be bought
wi●hout great paine, ād good dedes wrought
Els man cannot them haue.

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Stop thereat, and hold thy peace
May not men by hea●en with richesse
As to bylde churches and make bye wayes
Such deedes mans soule doth sans

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Yea, ●ut yet ye ●ust marke one s●ynge
yf these goodes came with wro●ge doyng
Shall ye haue heauen for so spendynge
Or yet a●y mede.
Nay nay except that ma● himselfe doo meeke
And make resysta●ce the ryght ho●our to seeke
Els all such good dedes is not woth a leeke
welth hereof take heede.

sp.speaker: wealth.
sp.l: Why thinkest thou that all men which h●th welth
Getteth theyr goodes with brybry and s●ealeth
Thy repor●e is nought therfore Helthe
I counsell thee to ●ay the best.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: So I wyll, but yet I must say true
And ●ow a lyttle more I wyll say to you
Much sorowe and care w●lth doth ●rewe
He i● seldome in rest.
when a man is a lyttle hit and welthy
A●d hath in his ●hes●e treasures plentye
Then wyl he wrangle, and do shreudly
By his power and might.
With his neigh●oures he wyll go to lawe
And a wreke his malyce for valew of strawe
welth is fykle and out ●f awe
wylfull in wronge or ryght

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Thou speakest with a slaunderous tong●
All of euyll wyll, and yet it is wro●●e
welth in this realme hath bin louge
Of me commeth great honour.
Because that I welth ●ath great port●
All the worlde, hy●her doth resorte
Therfore I w●l●h, am this realmes comfort,
And here I wyll indure.

sp.speaker: Helth.
sp.l: So I wold ye shou●●, and I shall do the same
Helth I am called, and that is my name
If I would not abyde heare I were to blame
For here I am well cheri●hed
Yet say your selfe, nhw indifferen●ly
And if euery man doo not loue me
Helth as well as welth, yes verely
Therof I dare be reported

sp.speaker: We●th.
sp.l: Why should they loue thee● that wo●lde I knowe
As wel as me, I pray you showe
I am the superiour of hi● and lowe
No man may compare with me.

sp.speaker: Helth.
sp.l: To shew why I wyll not be afraied
For I can bide by that I ●aue sayde
Yf welthy men be very well apayd
Or muche they set you by.
But of welth, if they haue neuer so much
Goodes, tryasure and golde, and be called rych
Yet yf they lacke helth, there payne is suche
That they were better dye.
A man to were golde, and be in pay●e
What ioy hath he? none, but would be fayne
To giue all his treasure for helth playne
Or els he were very mad:
For if a man be neuer so poure
Yet if he haue helth, that is a treasure,
Then for his liuing, he may laboure
And in his harte be glad,

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: I neuer marked thus muche, nor vnderstood
That Helth was such a treasure, and to man so good
Wherfore I am sory, a●d I wil chaunge my moode
Now I pray you forgiue me.

sp.speaker: Heal●h
sp.l: I will forgiue or els I were to blame
And I pray you to forgiue me the same
I loue you hartly, and wyll prayse your name
yf it please you to keepe my company.

div.stage: ¶Here entreth lyberty with a so●g & after speaketh

sp.speaker: libert
sp.l: Why tary syrs whether are ye going
I see well ye looked not for my commi●g
Loe, out of syght out of remembry●g
Abse●ce is cause of strau●gnes,
What looke ye on werwhy are ye so straunge
From your fellow liberty, doth your minds chaūge
I● your company I was wont to range
What nedes all this busines,

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: By liberty now I doo not set
Seyng that helth and I am met
As feloweh together no man shall let
Me for to loue hym best.

sp.speaker: liberty.
sp.l: Let me heare what ye do say
Then ye are about to cast me away
How happes this? mary then I may
Goe pyke strawes and take me rest.
I pray you tell me whom I haue o●fended
yf I haue made a faute it shalde amended
with so shorte warning let me not be voyded
I crow yet ye do but iest.

sp.speaker: He●th●
sp.l: Why do ye make this cauelacion
we entende to make no alteracyon
welth and I haue had communication
He is my freende of olde.

sp.speaker: liberty
sp.l: What was the matter, I pray you tell
Me thinkes I ought to be of counsel
Or els I promyse you ye doo not well
With you I should beholde.

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: The matter is doone we are agreed
To reason it more it shall not neede
O brother helth, thou art in deede
More preciouser then golde.

sp.speaker: liberty.
sp.l: Gods bodi how commeth this gere to pas
I am cast out at the cartes arse
The worlde is nothing as it was
For I am here refused

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Why be you angry that we doo agree
Then are ye not wy●e, for if ye loue me
I will loue hym agayne, so it should be
Or els I were mysaduised

sp.speaker: ●●libert
sp.l: Then of my loue ye set no store
My company I see well ye looked notfore
Farewell I wyll get me out of the doore
yet I am your betters and so am I called.

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Such presumptuouse wordes wyll haue a fall
your comparyson is but feble and small
What can ye do nothyng at all
As you haue reputed.

sp.speaker: liberti.
sp.l: What were ye both two, were not I.
Wretches and caytyfes, looke not so hye
Thinke no scorne hardly
For I may be your peare
yf welth haue neuer so much substaunce
Lacking Libertye and we●r in duraunce
Within a whyte, I am in assurance
ye woulde pray me come nere.
Yf Helth be neuer so lust and stronge
yet if Lyberty were kept from him longe
Then sorow and care wolde be his songe.
yt would abate your cheare.
Fye of welth which lacketh ●ybertye
Fye of Helth and be in captiuitie
Fye of riches and lack good company
Lyberty hath no pere,
Wyll ye heare how he doth clatter?
What neede ye to rehearse all this matter.
ye know that we twayne afore any other.
Lyberty must nedes haue styll.
Lybertie o● vs is glade to wayte
ye sta●de to farre i● your owne conceyte
I wys lybertye ye ran make no bayte
To catche vs at your will.

sp.speaker: liberty●
sp.l: Now there ye lye, I can suffer no lo●ger
Welth for Libertye doth lobo●re euer
Aud helth for Libertye is a great store
Therfore set me not so lyght

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Libertye I pray the reasou no more
ye are welcome to vs as ye were before
In dede of liberty it is great suter
Therfore welcome by this lyght

sp.speaker: liberty●
sp.l: Now I thanke you both full kindly
your strange wordes a lytle did grene me
And now at your cōmaūdement I am redy
Aud at your owne wyll.

div.stage: ¶Here entreth with some iest yll wyll

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Mary I am come at the first call
Wyll, your owne man haue me who shall
For I am will seruaunt to you al
Ye shall not neede to sende for me.

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Who is acquanted with this man
He is very homely aud lytle good he can
To come in here so boldly, then
D●●ue him away quickly,

sp.speaker: W●ll.
sp.l: Why, I cam not tyll C was called
your owne wyll opeuly ye named
Then I came a pace lest I should be blamed
Ther●ore I pray you let me hyde styll,
Whose wyll, or what wyll, doth he meane
Thou art not my wyl, I forsake thee cleane
My wyl and their wylles is often sene
Our wylles can none yll

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Alas good masters I can none yll
yet by my trouth I am your euyll wyll
your wil, & your will, & yonr will, therfore keepe m●
I loue ye by goddes mother,

sp.speaker: liberty.
sp.l: This is a straunge saying vnto me
My wyl, your wyll, and his wyll, this cannot be
For in our wyles is great diuersitie
For one is not lyke another,

sp.speaker: ●yll.
sp.l: Yet by Christ your owne wyl I am
The maddest wyl, and the meriest, than
For goddes sake now, let me be your man
Tyl ye haue better acquaintaunce.

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: I perceyue this felow is kynde
And oweth to vs good wyl and mynde
Some kindes agayne then let hym finde
Let him haue some furderauuce

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: By god ●ir and I durst be so bolde
A●quaintance of this man clayme I would
and ky●ted to, yf the trouth were tolde
we be of one consangnynitie

sp.speaker: H●alth
sp.l: How so? let me here that I pray thee hartly

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Wyl and lyberty●is, of aunci●erie olde
with ont lyber●ye, wil● dare not be●olde
And where wyl lacketh, lybertye is full colde
Thyrfore wyl and lybertye must nedes be of kyn.

sp.speaker: liberti.
sp.l: In dede as he saythe it may well be
For wyl euer longeth vnto lybrtye
Therfore good freende welcome to me
I praye you al be good to him

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: For your sake he is welcome to b● all
Let him come to our place an● than he shall
Haue succoure of vs and helpe withal
& now we wil ●epart. And welth & helth goth out.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Wyl ye go hence. I thanke ye masters with al my hert
I wyl s●ke you out I warra●t you feare not
Now they be gone I am glad by saint mary
A lyttel while heare I purpose to tary
How to deceyue welth, helth, and libertie
Now must I deuyse.
For I am a chylde that is pas grace
I wyll I am called that in euery place
Doth much mi●chiefe this is a playne case
Uertue I doo vtterly dispise,
But if they wyst what I were
Then of my purpose I should be neuer y^●●ere
I wyl kepe my ●onge le●●e that I ●●r.
My whole intent and wyll.
But now I meruayle by this day
Where shrewd wit is gone a stray
Some crafty touche is in his way
I here him, peace, stand styll
¶Dien vous garde playsaunce
On seuen or no ●●●chaunce, what youkers dare auaunte
To playe a grote or twaine.
Loe heare I haue in store
Two or three grotes and no more
I take great thought therfore
For to kepe it, it is much payne
I come uow out of a place
where is a company of small grace
Theues and hores that spendes a pace
They were dronken all the sorte.
One of their purces I did a spy
Out of his sleue where it dyd lye
And one wynked on me with his eye
But ther began the sporte
Their false falsehode, and I crafty wyt
got the purse loe, heare I haue it
I ran my way and let hym syt
Smoke and shitten arse together.
And yf that I had yll wyll here
with this money we wolde make good chere
Gentle brother wyll, I pray the apeare
For thou art in some corner.

sp.speaker: Wytte
sp.l: I woulde come in but I am a fearde
Least that I be taken by the bearde
Wyth some catchepol, I haue heard
How thou haste stollen a purse

sp.speaker: wytte
sp.l: Thou horsou art thou mad, cum in I say
This is not the fyrste hazard that I haue scaped
yf I make au hand to decke my felfe gay
what am I the worse.

sp.speaker: wyll
sp.l: From thy company I cannot abyde
I must ●edes holde vpon ●hy syde
y●●wyll and shrewd wit who ca● hyde
For they will be together.

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: Now welcome wyll and what ch●a●●:
By god I thought for thee a tho●sand yere
P●ace for gods body who cummeth there
Hauce bere pot Ascon router.
Gut nyuen s●one rutters by the moder got
It ●eist ōwne s●hon, for s●aue ye ne●e
De qus●eker mau iche bie do do
Uan the groate bnmbarde well ic we●e
Dartyck dowsant van enhebit mete
Ic best de mauikin van de keining dangli●er
De grot keyser kind ic bene his ●usket●r

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Her● ye not d●onkē hance how he be gius to pra●e
The ma low perte slemi●ge is a lit●le to cheke mate

sp.speaker: wytte
sp.l: Let the knaue aloue, for his name is war.
Such dronken sl●miniuges your company wilmar

sp.speaker: Hance.
sp.l: Ic bes● nen emond, ic best in soche
ye secte nete vell ic fors●aue ye in doche

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: C●●pt hore leyf with yo●r gound stand nere
yt be●ummes you better to handle a potte of beare

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Dat maght ic vell dan, ic can skynke fr●lyck
Tab bers fr●w, ic bri●ges brore, begot●s nemerick

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: The horse● k●a●● by ●he ●es●e is dronke
A winking for dep● his eyen be cleane lonck

sp.speaker: Hauce
sp.l: Ic ●or●●e ye vell ye seg dac ic ●●ope
Ne nike, u● nike, ic compta ho●e for an aud or cope.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Wel coppin I pray the hartly tell vs trew
Wherfore comest thou hether for any thi●g to sew

sp.speaker: Hanc●
sp.l: ye icke f●g●r en būbardere vā de koyni●g wei it be
Heb twe skelling de dagh ic c●n scote de culueryn

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: Nay ye shall walke a fleming knaue, wyl ye not see
We haue English g●nners ynow, there is no rome empty

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Ic best en ●om●erde mo●ye to m● spreken
what segye ye bones, it sal ye yode sta●n

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: We speake not to thee thou art a s●one man
But goe thy way they be not here that promot y^● cā

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Cant ye me a de house dragen van degrot here.

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: Hauce ye must go to y^● court & for welth inquire

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: What segre ye welth nenyke he is net hore
welth best in s●aunders, it my self brought him dore

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Be shrew your horson s●eminges hert therfore.
in dede as he saith, by war in ●laūders theris welth store

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Segt ye dat brower, by the moder got dan
Gut naught it mot waft, to sent cafrin to mi laninā

sp.speaker: wyll.
sp.l: Is he gone, farewel hanykin howse
I pray god giue him a hounded drouse
For I trow a knaue brought hym to house
But now brother wyt.
We must deuo●e how that we may
Be in seruice with welth alwaye
Let me here what thou canst do or say
To helpe for to contryue it.

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: For thy pleasure that I shall
This wyll I doo first of all
Flatter and lye, and euermore call
Them my good maysters styll.
Then with swering, lying and powlinge
Brybry theft, and preuy pyking
Thus I shred wet, wyll euer be doinge
I warrant ther yll wyll.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: I ●un thee thanke, this is well deuysed
And I yll wil, wolde haue euery man dispised
B●● now another thing must be con●riued
O● els al wilbe nought
There is one they call good remedy
I● this realme, he hath gee●t actor●●y
He is a no●le m●● and much worthy
M●ny thiuges he hach wrought
He is called l●st, discreete and indifference
Willing to fulfil his souer●i●es commaundement
H● is not fraide to do right punishment
T●erfore of him I am afrayde

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: So an I to this maketh me very sadde
Yet oftentymes I h●●e bene harde bestadde
N●w y^t I ●m ●a●ned of him I am v●ry glad
〈◊〉 c●aft● w●le for him ●h●l●e ha●e

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: P●●ce no mo wordes but 〈◊〉
M● think I ●eare mast welth ca●●
K●●le do●●e 〈…〉 deuout orison
T●●t they may heare vs pr●y
N●w 〈…〉 Welth, He●●h, aud L●bertie.
Liberty and helth retur●eth back with welth

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.l: S●rs you sh●ll haue bo●●●ods blessing
S●●ce ●e worth for ●our praying
ye are wel disposed and of good liuing
I w●ll loue you the ●erteral way

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Sir this do we vse euer● day
F●r w●●th helth and liberty 〈◊〉●ray
This sa●● is m● brother, 〈…〉
He is an hard honest man.

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: For●oth ma●●ter I am his ●rother
To be 〈◊〉 ser●a●●, was my cū●ing hether
A● lo●ge as we two be to gether●
ye shall not pe●y●he than

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: To haue you both 〈◊〉 seruyce I am content
How say you libertie wil you therto consen●
Wyll and wit, god hath vs lent
We may be glade of them

sp.speaker: liberti.
sp.l: Yf we sholde refuse wyl and wyt
we were to blame ●or they be fyt
Therfore by my wel they shal not ●lye
They be welcome to me,

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: God thanke you mais●ers all three
ye shal finde vs pore but 〈◊〉 we cannot be
My tonge stom●les, I cry you mercy
We wyll be true I should ●ay,

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Syrs go your way home vnto one place
And w● wyl hye vs after ●pace
And when we come we shall set you in case
To hau● a lyuing ●lway.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Th●n loke ye do both truely and iust
For we must put you in great 〈◊〉
All our hou●houlde guide y● must
B●haue you selfe well.

sp.speaker: wytte
sp.l: Maisters feare not for I h●●e wit i●ough
To beguyle my selfe, and 〈◊〉 beguyle you
I haue begyled many one I may say to you
I pray you kepe that in councelll

sp.speaker: liberty.
sp.l: Beware of that, what doth he say?
Beguyle vs all, yet I charge ye ●ay
Ye shall not beguile vs yf I may
I wyl beware betyme.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Syr be not angry I you praye
●he foole woteth not he doth say
He meneth ●hat he wil be profitable alway
And saue you many thinges.

sp.speaker: Health●
sp.l: What he meaneth I can●ot te●●
But his saying is not well
Depart hence syrs by my councell
And tary vs at our lodging.

sp.speaker: wy●●e.
sp.l: ¶Now and it please ye, wyll ye ●ere any synging
Therein I tell you I am s●●what ●o●nyng
ye shall heare and ye list.

sp.speaker: lib●r●y
sp.l: Syr I pray you sing and ye ran

sp.speaker: w●ll.
sp.l: Now wil I begin like a lusty bloud thā.
Sirs now go your way of you I am glad
As of any ser●auntes that euer I had
For these can do doth good ●●o bad
We must needes haue such men
What were we yf we lacked wyll:
And without ●yt we ●●oulde lyue yll
Therfore wyll and wit I wyll ●epe styll.
I promise you I loue them

div.stage: ¶Here commeth remedy in and to him saith

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Syr your maystership is ●a●tely welcome
T●ke your place here aboue as it is reason.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: I pray you ●ardon vs, we know not what ye be
ye seme a man of honour, and of great anctority

sp.speaker: liberty
sp.l: S●r to know wherfore ye come we are desyrons

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: I am be that ought for to be well knowen
Of you thre specially, and of duetie
Great payne and busines as for mine owne
For you I haue taken because I lo●e you hartely
To m●i●taine you is all my de●yre and faculty
yet hard it is to doo, the people be so variable
And many be so wilfull, they will not be reformable.

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Syr I pray you pardon vs of our ignoraunce now
I se well ye know vs better tha● we do yo●

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: I pardon you, for I doo know you w●l both
wel●h, and ●●l●h, is your 〈…〉
Th● which ●ngla●d to forbe●e were very lot●
For by welth and helth commeth ●re al sa●●es
Many other ●e●●●nes ●or our gre●t welth ●●ames
T●a● they ●a●e not pre●ume, nor thy dare no●●e bold

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: To stry●e againe En●la●d or a●y right with holde.

sp.speaker: remedi
sp.l: Sir ye be welcom, I de●e●h you show ●s your name

sp.speaker: liberti.
sp.l: Good remedy forsouth I 〈◊〉 the s●me
yf I 〈◊〉●o bolde● I wolde pray you har●ely
To sh●we vs apart of you● great ac●oritie,

sp.speaker: ●●md
sp.l: My actoritie is geuen to ●e most speciall
To maintaine you three, in this realme to be
What mine intent is. I wyl tel, ●u● not all
For that were to longe to reher●e of a surety
And I desyre you all or to be louing ●o me
For your owne ease, come w●lth and profyt

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.l: Good remedy, then we ●anst des●re yo●r aydyng
For by good remedy cometh all ou● preferri●g.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: All that I doo intende, if ye● wil therto agr●e
And to be reformable for your owne case
It is not the thynge that lieth only in me
But my good wyl, therfore I wyl not cease
To haue your loue a●d fauour, and thereby to please
Al the worlde ouer, and to promote ●his realme
That you thre may prosper, ye perce●ue what I mene
The chiefe parte of all welth lyeth in great estates
Theyr substance and landes. is right commendable
Prelates of the churche is welthy of ryches
Merchaūtes hath marchaūdise & goods iucōperable
Mē of ●aw & franklins is welthy which i● laudable
Th●s welth of riches is deuided diuerse wayes
A●d to these ma●● charges, come now a dayes

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: My hert re●o●se●h to ●er● your good reporting
〈◊〉 are we bound to god, which prouideth althing

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Forsoth here is 〈◊〉 half● that I cou●● re●erse
The benefits of god that ●e sheweth to you welth
Co●sider Englysh men, how va●iant they be & fer●e
O● al nacious ●one such, when they haue their ●elth
No land can do vs ●arme, b●● wyth falle●●d or ●elth
r●mēbre what nōbre of m●● or a●●●erie● good ord●nā●e
Specially y^e grace of god, which is our 〈◊〉 forderāce
If there be any that wyll grudge, surm●●● or ●●o
Againe welth, helth & libertie, then ●●st I for y^e ●●●e
Sh●w ●ine auctoritie and power, for ●o remedy it ●o
That no●e of you shall diminishe nor amiss● be ●ane
I good remedy therfore may & will speak● won● blāe
For the comen welth, & helth both of the soule & b●dy
y^● is mi office & power, & therfore I haue my actoritie

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Our lorde con●inue ye, & we thanke you har●ly
Both for your good i●struction, and for your kindnes
That you int●nd● so wel for vs good remedy
when we haue nede we will desyre your goodnes

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: When we be infect in the soule or body
Then will I seke good remedy for succo●r
As yet I thanke god I haue no nede greatly
yf I haue then wyll I seke to haue your fauour

sp.speaker: liberty
sp.l: Syr now we wyl departe hence with yo●r licence

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: For other diuers busines that we mus● haue tohether
Sirs I am coutent, now when ye wyll depart
To god I commyt yo● I wyll not make you tary
But yet I pray with all my minde and heart
Take hede in any wise exchewe yl & shrewd compani
y● a mā be neuer soo ●ood & vs●〈…〉 be ●ut●rist●̄
He shalle ●e his name, & to some vice they wil him tēp
●herfore bewar● of such people, & ●eom thē be exemp●

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: yes yes I warrant you of s●c● I wyll beware.
Farewel good remedy & wel to fare.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: I pray god be ●our spede & preserue you frō paine
it is mi mind ye shold prosper I wold haue it so ●ain.

sp.speaker: W●ll.
sp.l: Here is none of our acquaiutaūce wil re●our●eth
we haue made to louge tar●aunce
that wyll y● say perc●●unce
Aud they begone home come away apar●

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: Nay by god not so ●astie
A lytle whyle we wyll larye
Good euen s●r to you mary
Dwell ye in this place?

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Nay good fellowe I dwel not ●eare
Wherefore doest thou ●hat inqui●●:
Woldest thou ought with any ●eare
Speake ●e not afryde

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: By God I would I had yo●r gowne
Aud were a myle without the towne
Theron A woulde borowe a crowne
It is I that so sayde

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: Hew lookest thou one him halfe a scorne
I p●omise you he is a scant gentylman bor●e
What sūy●st thou in his face

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: For somwhat in his face I lok●e
Iu dede his mastership standes a crook●
For false shrewes both of you I tooke
And chyldren that be past grace.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: I wyll swere for hym, as ●or this yeares twenty
that he hath ben euer as true as I
yet sometyme he will steale and make a 〈◊〉
He is of my alyaunce.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: In good fayth the same thinke I
That ye be both lyke, full vnthrifty
Syrs how do ye lyue, shew me quickly
Or I shall put you in duraunce

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: How liue we? mary our meate
Cummest thou hether for to threte:
So lordly syr wittam doth speake
From wh●n●e doth he come can ye shewe

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: What dost thou ayle canst thou tell?
Hast thou any thing with vs to mell?
By the masse thy handes doth tykell
Thou shalt beare me a blowe.

sp.speaker: remedi
sp.l: you false theues I know ye well
I shall let your purpose ●u●y deale
yll wyll, and shrewd wit, the deuyll of hell
Take ye both for me.

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: Mary thou lyest, our names be not so
Call vs but wit, and wyll, adde no more thereto,
yf thou doest thou were as good no
We shall handle you shrewdly

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Syrs farewell here I wil no longer abide
For you both shortly I wyll prouide
Tha● all your ●al●e craft shalbe out tryed
And our subtillitie knowen

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: To go so soone the horson was wyse
therfore some now I must deuise
that each man may welth, helth and liberti despise
Or els he wyll marre all our mateer.
Brother wat, let me alone
When they come you shal see me a none
C●mplayne of him● vnto them ec●one
And put him out of fauour

sp.speaker: Wytte
sp.l: Peace no mo word●s, for they come yonder

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Syrs I am glade that you h● heare
How doth all our houshold● with them what chere●
Is euery thi●g in order there
A●ir● our intente?

sp.speaker: wyll.
sp.l: ye syr they be all mery and glad
With reuell and ●out somtime they be mad
Pipe whore bo●t heef, euery knaue and drabe
Is at our commaundeme●t.
What do ye say, then ●e are to blame
A●d we put you in trust for the same
To kepe such rule, it is a shame
It is not for our honour●

sp.speaker: wy●●e.
sp.l: By the masse ●he horson doth lye
There is no such rule by gods body
A man may breke his ●eck as lyghtly
As his fast in your kechin, or seller truly.
With that nother I am ●o● co●te●t
I wolde there should be libera●itie compe●ēt
A●d with honesti it is con●enient
That our nei●hbour fare the better

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: you be a●g●y with all that we haue done
Cum away brother let vs go ●eus soone
I know a n●w m●ister wher we shalbe welcum●
God be with ●ou gentyl maister

sp.speaker: Welth.
sp.l: Why wil ye begone ●or a worde
P●raduenture we did but boorde
Me thinke ye should your mayster foorde
For to speake my minde.

sp.speaker: wytte
sp.l: Nay ●ay, I can tel what was the matter
Remedy was here, and he dyd ●latter
ye trust he more than vs and better
But marke the ende, what ye shal find

sp.speaker: H●alth
sp.l: With good remedy we spake iu dede
To ●●low his counsel we had neede
He warned vs that we should take hede
Of excesse and prodigalitie.

sp.speaker: Wytte
sp.l: I meruayle ye speake so of good remedy
It is I that can do more than be
Wyt can make shyft at necessit●
When Remedi cannot be hearde
I know some that hath this thousand yere
Sought god remedy and yet neuer the nere
wit can put remedy by, yea this is cleare
For wit is a crafty lad.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: And wyl is an vngracious stay
Wyl hath doone many thinges me● say
And yf ye let wit and wil goe his way
ye wil repent it soone.

sp.speaker: liberty
sp.l: Why what cause haue you to go your way
ye shall abyde wich vs though you say nay
I wyl folow wyl, and wit alway
And so I haue euer done

sp.speaker: wytte.
sp.l: yf I wilt al my masters wolde so do
Then from your seruyce I wolde ●ot goo
Speake ●ow whe●her ye wyl or no
And let vs know your minde

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Syrs ye be welcome to me playne
And for your company I am full fayne
I had leuer suffer great payne
Then to leue my wit aud wyl,

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Then let vs go hence, with ki●dnes my herye do kyll

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: I pray you let vs go, wherfore do we byde styll.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: As touching my first purpose hither I am com again
I trow ye k●ow me, good remedy is my name
That euery day doth take great● abor or payne
To amende all faultes, I am chosen to the same
yf any ma●s conscience here doth grudge or shame
Hauing in him self remorse, & mendes in tyme & space
I am good remedy, and god is ful of mercy and grace
Therfore I wyl stand asyde, & a lyttel whyle remaine
Of welth, Helth and Lybertye, for to inquire
How they be ordred, and yf any man complayne
I wil be glad to shew me remedy, my think I se one a||peare.

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Begots drowse it my selfe bin cūpt heye scō lansiu●

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Ic mot in ander land lo●en, al is quade dan

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Thou fleming frō whēce comest y^● & what dost y^u here●

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Ic my self cumt frō sent Katryns dore mot ic skyn● de cā beer

sp.speaker: Hanc●
sp.l: Get y^● thether againe, & tary here no lōger

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Syr ic mot mid ye spreken ic my self be en scomaker

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: What and thou be therwith I haue nothin a doo.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Ic dest al forlore, copin is dod, ic maght aot do ther●o

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: I pray thee go hence, for thou dost trouble me yll.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Nen ic seker, ic wyl not gon, ic wold fain liue hore stil
There is to mainy allaunts in this reale, but now I
good remedy haue so prouided that English men shall
lyue the better dayly.

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: What segt ye by got● drowse, dai is de quade man
Be de moro goi, ic my selfe loue descone Englishmau.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Fie on y^e flatteri●g knane, fie ou you aliaūts al I ●ay
ye can w^t craft & subtel ●iget engl●shmēs welth away

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: O skon mester, ic heb hore bin, this datten yeore
ic ●●nskote de colue●in● & ic can be or beare droer●
trust see so pro●ide that welth fromy●n haue I shall

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Ic seg to you dat welth is lopen in an a●der cont●y
wat he beg● dar brough, for●tan ye net, segt me

sp.speaker: Rem●●
sp.l: Ic vnderstand the wel, yet thou liest lyke a knaue
welth is here ī Englād, & welth stil i trust we shal haue

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Ic ment no quad ic loue de english man 〈◊〉 min ●ere
Cūp vp sent Katrin and ic shal ye geuē two ●lope bere,

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Get y^e hence drōkē ●leming y^u shalt tary no le●ger here

sp.speaker: Hance
sp.l: Mor it net mare here bin, woder sal ic gewest kiskin
Ic wil to de Kaizer gan, dar sall ic wal skinkin

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Is he gon● I pray god the deuyll go with him
wher is welth, helth & ●iberty. I wold see thē come i●

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Helth commeth in with a kercher on his head.
¶O good lorde helpe me, by yonr licence my souerain
I am homely to com her in your presēce thus diseased
Nede constraineth me, for remedy I wold haue faine
I am īfect both body & soul, I prai you be not displesed

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Why what aile you shew me, yet you I do not know
Glad I am to remedy auy man, that is affirmity
I perceiue by your phisnamy, y^t ye ar veri weke feble & low
yet show me your g●iefe, & I wil help you gladl●.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Gracio{us} remedi I tha●k you, yet I am half ashamed
to shew you mi maladi & mi name, I was cal●ed helth
Therfore I am wel worthi to be punished & blamed
Because I haue not folowed your coūsel, but al thing
may be suffered saue welth.

sp.speaker: Remdy
sp.l: Are you helth, this maketh me very pe●●i●e and sad
yet be of good chere, & show how you were infect
To remedy you a●d succour you I wold be very glad
For god wyl pu●ish the people when they be de●elt

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Syr I thanke god therof for wel worthy I am
My conscien●e doth iudge, some trouble haue I must
A me●des I wyl make to god and if I can
Wil ād wit hath deceiued me in them I put my trust.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: yf thou haue ●oone amisse, and be sory therfore
Then helfe ame●des is made, for that is contrission
Let that passe, now wil I axe you one thyng more
Wher be welth ād Libertie, be they of good disposiciō

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: As for welth is fallen iu decay, and neces●itie
By wast & war, thorow yll wyll, and ●hrewd wit
And lybertie is kept in duraunce and captiuite
God helpe vs all, and sende vs good remedy for it

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: For to heare this tale it maketh my hart heauie
yet be of good cōfort, god is ful of grace, & I am good

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: ¶Sir, thē I besech you help vs in the way of charity

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: I would fayne but I cannot tel which way to begin
Except I might catch wil & wi●, then I trow I could
Tye thē shorter, for they destroy welth, helth & liberty bi sin
yf I had y^e theues, puni●h thē extremly I wole.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: You may soone catch them, if ye wil stande a syde
From this place they two, wyl uot●onge abide.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Me thinke●h I here them com, helpe to holde thē fast will turneth
Cum in wit for here is no body
We may ve bolde and talke largely
Our hartes to ease and shew plainly
What we haue doone.

sp.speaker: wytte
sp.l: I must nedes laugh I cannot forbeare
To remember war●e that knaue wil ye heare
The horson fleming was be ●●itten for feare
Because he should boyde so soone.
Herke now do I meruayle by this bread

sp.speaker: W●ll.
sp.l: For I we●● surely ●hat h●lth be dead
I saw saw him go with a kercher on his head
As he should go to hangyng.

sp.speaker: ●ytte
sp.l: Harke in thine Eare, yf t●●e horson hap
To complayne to him that weres the red cap
I feare theu shortly he wyl vs cla●
By the heles from out liuing●

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Nay nay, there is no doubt
By hym I haue reported all about
Tha● he doth not wel, his good name to put out
ylwyl cannot say wel,

sp.speaker: remedi.
sp.l: Frende therin thou art the more to blam
Cos●au●der me wro●gfully, and vudesr●ued
But or thou drpart thou shalt answere for the same.
wher is Welth & liberty, how hast thou thē ordred?

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Qury cicis quest is vn malt ombre
Me is vn spy & nardo compoco pa●lauere.

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Thou folse thefe is thine English tonge gone
as mischeuo{us} il wil & shrewd wit, ye haue destroyd ma||ni on

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: Sir hurt not me, & I wil tel you trouth anone
This same i● as false a knaue as euer cam w^tin saint Iohēs

sp.speaker: wyll.
sp.l: Per amorde my as pi ca vn poco
Eo queris and a● pour lag●●●n● creae so

sp.speaker: Remdy
sp.l: I can not tel what thou dost m●ae blabbler:
But y^u shalt speake English & confesse an other mater,

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Syr I besech your lordship, in the way of charity
Let not these thefes escape your hands they haue de|stroyed vs v●terly.

sp.speaker: wytte:
sp.l: Syr, beleue hym not he speakes but of malice onely
we be true men, therof we shall fetch good witnes
An honest man that shalbe bound for him and me
The law sayth plaine, nulla fides con●●●●estes
that is trouth, but who wilbe witnes or boūd for the

sp.speaker: Remd
sp.l: There is three amonge you in this howse

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: I Iyf●o to fetch them quickly

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: They wil come vnsēd for I warant you if they wyll

sp.speaker: Remd
sp.l: what be theyr names, tel me what they be,

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: That on is Iohn Irische and Iohn s●oler
But ful these be honest men all thr●●●

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Trust not their wordes they wyll dessemble styll
They are so false and cra●●y, all ●heyr intent is yll.

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: ye lye falsely, I ●peake but right a●d reason
And by the law of armes ye must ned●s be ●ane
you a●e called good remedy which a● al feason
Sholde leaue to mans lyfe, and ma●●taine the same
we be he●e ●oth your prisoners wrongfully accused bi de●ame
Kepe ou● of vs fast let him lye for all
That other sor frendes and wytnes goo shall.

sp.speaker: wyt●e,
sp.l: Syr let hym not goo a●d le●e me behynde
He wyl euer ●e a false knaue, for I k●ow his mynde

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Holde thy tonge folis● k●aue I do not meane so

sp.speaker: Remd●
sp.l: I here now ye ca●not agre, which of you should go

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: No by gods body there shall none go but I

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: Tho● playest the knaue it must nedes be I

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: Kepe them safe I pray you for yf they scap againe
Many me● shal repent it, it shal●e to our pay●e

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: They be here yet, to kepe them fast is myne inteut,
Haue them away both to prison in continent.

sp.speaker: wyll.
sp.l: Lo false knaue this is for thy crafty wi●.
Now fast by the heeles we are lake to syt.

sp.speaker: Wytte.
sp.l: I am co●●ent so that I may haue comp●ny
yf I shold be hanged, I wold be hāged honest

sp.speaker: Remd●
sp.l: Go bence with them & bring welth & liberty.

sp.speaker: helth,
sp.l: Com away ye thenes, now I shall kepe you s●rely,

sp.speaker: Wyll.
sp.l: Lock vs vp & kepe vs as fast as ye can
yet yll wyl and ●●rewd wit shalbe with many a man.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: I am halfe ashamed, that long i● hath ben sayd
That noble men by such wretches hath ben decei●ed
they did reioyce and iest, and were very well apaide
Trusting to ●cape clea●e, and ●tyl for to haue rained
But now they shall not so, let them be wel assured
That ylwyl and shrew de wyt shal haue but yl rest
For wheresoeuer they be I wyll break● theyr nest

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: In the honour of god we aske you forgeue●es al th●e
we ought to be ashamed ●o looke you in the face
By our foly & negligence, we haue done so vnwisely
we were towle deceyued, we p●t vs to your grace
Thys shalbe a good warding for vs alonge space
whan man is wel punished then he wyl beware
w●o that knoweth what nede is, wel after drede ●are

sp.speaker: Remd●
sp.l: I may not blame you gretly for by mine owne reasō
I know ylwyl and shrewd wit deceiueth great & smal
yf ye can remābre thys● and beware a ●other season
This is a good example and lerni●g to you all
Now serue god and loue him, & for grace euer call
And ylwyl and shrewde wyt, from yo● I shall ab●taine
ye haue vs●d them to longe to your domage and pain.

sp.speaker: health.
sp.l: Forsoth syr ye sai trouth, they did vs great disp●esur
Full hard it is to banquishe the vngr●cious ylwyl
He is so croked, by slattery, dissula●ion & such other
Mannes mynd i● so var●able, & glad to report yl
I feare many one yet wolde haue him raine styll
For some vnto their owne wyl hath so much affection
yet the devyl an● yl wyl is both of o●e complexion

sp.speaker: liberty●
sp.l: yll wyll is nought, but worse is shrewd wyt
For he contryueth al subtil ymanginacien
yt were vnpossyble for a man els to doo it
shrewd wyt breweth myscef● & false conspyracion
He hath put me lyberty in prison, ād great at tribulacion
if it had not bene for your good remedi & fortheraūce
I ● other y^t hath libertie, shold haue bē in duraunce.

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Be al of good chere, and haue no mistrust
The e●de of yl wyl and shrewd wyt is but shame
Though they reygue a while, wrongfully and vniu●●
yet truth wyll appeare and their misdedes blame
Then wro●ge 〈◊〉 su●●ued, and good remedy ta●●
Though ●alsehodeloke, and hide his matters all
Craft w●●l out and disce●te wyll haue a fall
Whereas ye are now, in distresse all three
Neare were ye brought in case lyke ●o marre
Now haue ye no dou●t, yf ye wyll ●e ruled after m●
I shal restore ye agayne as well as euer ye were
Welth kepe styll this realme, looke ye stray not fa●●
And Helth be of good chere, yo●r disease I ca● soone mēde
Liberty now ye ●e released do no more off●nd,

sp.speaker: wealth
sp.l: Now let vs al thāke god y^e good remedy hath s●ude
Trust to hym only for his grace and goodnes
we are forgiuenes o● our trespa● I trust we wil amēd
And cleane for●ake syn, foly, and vnthriftines
〈◊〉 we wil here cōclude, soueraine of your graciousnes
we besech you to ●emyt our negligence, & misbehauor
There we haue sayd amīs, we cōmit also your fauor

sp.speaker: Health
sp.l: And for your preseruacion hartely we wyl pray
your realme to increase, w●th ●oy a●d tranquility
That welth, helth & liberty, may co●tinne here alway
By the ouersight and aide of him that is good remdy
which willingly doth his deu●●, vnder your actoritye
As parte here apereth your p●rpose to mai●taine
God continue his good●es, that longe he may riagne

sp.speaker: Remdi
sp.l: Iesu preserne quene Elizabeth y^e noble prīcis worthy
Iesu continue her helth long for to endure
Ies● indue her w vertue grace & honour
Iesu maintaine the lords of y^e coūsel to exec●te good remedi euer
Iesu spede and helpe al them gods honour to further
Iesu increase the comunaltie to prosper and doo wel.
